title.narrative: DDG/MAG Global, Afghanistan and Iraq Mine Action Programme 2018-2021
DDG/MAG Global, Afghanistan och Irak mininsats 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Danish Demining Group (DDG) and Mines Advisory Group (MAG) have submitted a joint programme proposal to address the problems posed by the presence of anti-personal mines, cluster ammunition, Explosive Remnants of War (ERW), Improvised Explosive Devices (IED) and Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW). This 4-year programme will be conducted during 2018-2021 with a total budget of 320 MSEK, which will be evenly divided between the financial years. This contribution will be financed by three Swedish strategies: Sustainable Peace, Afghanistan and Iraq. The Sustainable Peace strategy will provide 200 MSEK while the other two bilateral strategies will contribute 60 MSEK each. The funding from the Sustaining Peace strategy has a tentative allocation of 160 MSEK to mine action and 40 MSEK to SALW.
DDG is an integral part of the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) and DRC is therefore the legal entity signing the agreement for this project and will be responsible for the funds transferred to MAG.
The country focus of the Sustainable Peace component finance will be determined on an annual basis to provide flexibility for adapting changing needs. DDG/MAG does, however, have long term strategies for most of the countries they are active in, since mine action require a long-term focus. The contributions that will be implemented through Sustainable Peace will focus on mines, cluster ammunition and other explosive remnants in the following eleven countries during 2018: -DDG is planning on implementing contributions in Algeria (with focus on West Saharan refugee camps), Colombia, Libya, Syria, Ukraine and Yemen. -MAG is planning on implementing contributions in Bosnia Herzegovina, Lebanon, Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe.
When deciding on where to work the aim has been to include both contexts with a focus on facilitating humanitarian response and contexts more focused on supporting the commitments toward the mine- and cluster conventions. This is also done to balance the risk profile of the intervention since countries with on-going conflicts pose higher risks in a number of areas.
Regarding SALW, DDG plan to focus on Guinea (as well as one additional country in West Africa) while MAG will work with SALW in Somalia.
The contribution in Afghanistan will be implemented by DDG alone since MAG is not active there, and Iraq will be the only country where both DDG and MAG will be implement the programme during 2018. This programme is a continuation of earlier support from Sida where the Sustainable Peace strategy has contributed to DDG and MAG during 2015-2017 as well as earlier Sida support to DDG in Afghanistan during 2010-2016. The programme aims to address the problems posed by the presence of anti-personnel mines, cluster ammunition, ERW, IED’s and SALW. Landmines, ERWs and IEDs poses a direct threat to innocent human beings, can hamper economic and social development, hinder or complicates humanitarian support to be delivered and make it hard for people (IDPs and refugees) to return. In order to reduce the threat posed and support safe returns, and contribute to social and economic development DDG/MAG plan to undertake clearance of anti-personnel mines and explosive devices, in combination with mine risk education and awareness raising activities. DDG and MAG collaborates on country level with national authorities (if the political situation allows collaboration) to establish which areas that should be prioritised for demining. DDG and MAG will also contribute to increased national capacity through the education of deminers, through collection of information about the extent of contamination in the country which will contribute to the development of the authorities’ databases and through dialogue with the authorities about the most effective demining methods. The authorities’ also play a crucial role in that they will conduct a quality assurance (if there is capacity) of the demining and to release cleared land back to the community.
The component of the programme that targets SALW will focus on mitigating the risks of unplanned explosions and the proliferation of SALW. This will be done through improving the Physical Security and Stockpile Management (PSSM) and the contribution in Somalia will furthermore contain marking and registration of weapons.

Danish Demining Group (DDG) och Mines Advisory Group (MAG) har inkommit med ett gemensamt programförslag för att adressera problematiken med minor, klusterammunition och andra explosiva lämningar av krig samt små och lätta vapen. Detta 4-åriga program löper under perioden 2018–2021 med en budget om totalt 320 MSEK jämt fördelat över programperioden. Programmet finansieras av tre svenska strategier: Hållbar fred, Afghanistan och Irak där den förstnämnda bidrar med 200 MSEK och de båda bilaterala strategierna med 60 MSEK vardera. Gällande finansieringen från Hållbar fred planeras att 160 MSEK allokeras till minhantering och 40 MSEK till små och lätta vapen.
Minhanteringsdelen av denna insats kommer utgöra en betydande del av Sveriges stöd till hantering av minor och klusterammunition och kommer således bidra till Sveriges åtaganden rörande Ottawafördraget om förbud mot minor och Konventionen om klusterammunition.
DDG sorterar under och ingår som en integrerad del av Danska flyktingrådet (DRC), som således är Sidas avtalspartner och som i sin tur vidareförmedlar resurser till MAG.
Landfokuset för finansieringen från Hållbar fred kommer att beslutas på årsbasis för att på ett flexibelt sätt möjliggöra att insatsen behovsanpassats i bästa möjliga mån. Samtidigt kräver minhantering långsiktighet vilket gör att DDG/MAG har en långsiktig ansats i de flesta utav insatsländerna. Under Hållbar fred kommer insatsen att genomföras med fokus på minor, klusterammunition och andra explosiva lämningar i följande 11 länder/kontexter under 2018: - DDG planerar att implementera insatsen i Algeriet med fokus på de västsahariska flyktinglägren, Colombia, Libyen, Syrien, Ukraina och Yemen. - MAG planerar att implementera insatsen i Bosnien och Hercegovina, Libanon, Myanmar, Sri Lanka och Zimbabwe.
För att bidra till att underlätta humanitära insatser och att bidra till att åtagandena gentemot min- och klusterkonventionerna samt för att sprida risken har DDG/MAG strävat efter att både inkludera länder med pågående konflikt och länder där konflikten har avslutats.
Dessutom planerar DDG att fokusera på små och lätta vapen i Guinea samt ytterligare ett land i Västafrika och MAG avser att arbeta med dessa frågor i Somalia.
Både DDG och MAG kommer att implementera insatsen i Irak och eftersom inte MAG är aktiva i Afghanistan kommer insatsen där att implementeras av DDG.
Programmet som bygger vidare på tidigare stöd från Sida där Hållbar fred strategin givit ett gemensamt stöd till DDG och MAG under perioden 2015–2017 samt tidigare Sida stöd till DDG i Afghanistan under perioden 2010–2016. Insatsen syftar till att adressera problemen som orsakas av minor, klusterammunition, explosiva lämningar av krig (ERW) och improviserade sprängladdningar (IED). Minor, ERW, IED:er utgör ett direkt hot mot oskyldiga människor, hindrar ekonomisk och social utveckling, försvårar leverans av humanitärt stöd och göra det svårare för människor på flykt att återvända hem. För att minska det direkta hotet och bidra till social och ekonomisk utveckling, planerar DDG/MAG att röja minor, explosiva lämningar och klusterammunition i kombination med utbildnings- och informationsinsatser riktade mot att öka medvetenheten om riskerna relaterade till minor och andra lämningar. På landnivå samarbetar DDG och MAG med nationella myndigheter där den politiska situationen möjliggör samarbete för att prioritera vilka områden som ska prioriteras. Dessutom bidrar DDG/MAG till ökad nationell kapacitet genom att utbilda minröjare, genom insamling av information om situationen beträffande explosiva lämningar i landet vilket bidrar till att utveckla myndigheternas databaser och genom att föra en dialog med myndigheterna om de mest effektiva röjningsmetoderna. Myndigheterna spelar också en viktig roll i att kvalitetssäkra minröjningen (där kapacitet finns) samt att återlämna röjd mark till befolkningen.
Programkomponenten som behandlar små och lätta vapen fokuserar på att minska riskerna för oplanerade explosioner av sprängmedel och ammunition samt motverka spridning av små och lätta vapen. Detta görs genom att förbättra den fysiska säkerheten och förvaltningen av vapen och ammunitionsdepåer (på engelska används termen Physical Security and Stockpile Management (PSSM) för detta arbete). Insatsen i Somalia kommer även att innehålla märkning och registrering av vapen.

sector.narrative: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war

title.narrative: Avtal mellan Sida och Danish Refugee Council angående the Global Mine Action Programme, insats 11605
Beslut om insats, DDG-MAG Global, Afghanistan och Irak mininsats 2018-2021, insats 11605

description.narrative: The global mine action programme 2018-2021 is implemented by Danish Demining Group (DDG) and Mines Advisory Group (MAG) and is funded by three Swedish development strategies: Sustainable Peace, Afghanistan and Iraq. Therefore, most of the results below are broken down per strategy. Overall programme outputs 2019: - 4,805,249m² of land contaminated by mines and other explosive remnants of war (ERW) released. (Globally 1,913,055m2, Afghanistan 1,953,216m2 and Iraq 938,978m2). - 9,104 mines, cluster munitions and other ERW safely removed/destroyed. - 825 Explosive Ordinance Disposal (EOD) spot tasks responded to. Which means that on average Sida provided funding that enabled the removal of approximately 2 potentially dangerous items each day of 2019. - 7,049 RE sessions conducted, benefiting 110,199 men, women, boys and girls. - 734 Teachers and/or Community Focal points Trained in delivery of RE sessions. - 1,084 weapons marked and registered. - 8 Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) storage facilities refurbished /constructed. - 278 state security forces trained in SALW management and best practice. Global component During 2019, DDG worked in Colombia, Guinea (Small Arms and Light Weapons focus), Libya, Myanmar, Syria, Ukraine and Yemen while MAG was working in Angola, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Lebanon, Myanmar, Somalia (SALW), Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe under the global component. DDG's work in Myanmar and MAG's in Angola was new for 2019 under Sida funding while the remaining countries also received funding in 2018. In 2019, 55,044 women, men, girls and boys received Risk Education (RE) in 2019 (in 2018, the number of people receiving RE was 42,933). Of these, 30 % were girls, 30 % boys, 21 % men and 19 % women). The Risk education was delivered in 2,270 which was more than double the target number of sessions for 2019 and significantly higher than the 1,534 RE sessions 2018. The targets for the number of people reached is significantly lower than the target set at the design of the programme in late 2017. Since these targets are not realistic they will be reviewed as part of the ongoing mid-term review. 1,913,055 m² of safe land has been released back to communities through cancellation, reduction and clearance of mine affected land, which is 109% of the target. In addition to this 6,146,311 m² of suspected hazardous land was released in Libya (this is more of a bureacratic effort since the national database included land that is assessed to have not been contaminated) Compared to the 92,713,748 m² of land cleared in 2018, the 2019 is much smaller, but the 2018 figure is high due to a large area being cancelled from clearance in Libya. A better comparison is if the Libya figures are removed and then the number of square meters cleared is significantly higher than in 2018. In 2019, land was cleared in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Lebanon, Sri Lanka, Ukraine and Zimbabwe, similar to the context of 2019. Other noteworthy results on mine action include: MAG and DDG have provided support to the development of National Mine Action Strategies and Standards in Angola, Colombia, Lebanon, Myanmar and Sri Lanka. In Myanmar, both DDG and MAG have been engaged in the process to establish a national mine action authority. In Ukraine, DDG continues to build a national mine action capacity, including the training of the State Emergency Services to conduct mine action. Regarding SALW, DDG continued to experience challenges in their work in Guinea and by the end of 2019 they decided to refocus this work to another context. Also, MAG's work in Somalia experienced challenges due to the volatile security situation and the organisation could not implement activities in Kismayo, Jubaland as planned. The weapons marking activities, which are done to allow for identification and tracking of diverted weapons, were instead implemented in Somaliland. Partly due to this challenge the number of weapons marked in 2019 was lower than the 7,000 target. 1,084 weapons were marked in 2019 which is also significantly lower than the 3,000 weapons marked in 2018. Furthermore, 278 state security forces trained in SALW management and best practice (11 of them in Guinea and 267 in Somalia), which is slighly over target. In Somalia, 1 armory for safe storage of weapons and 7 weapons cabinets were constructed in Jubaland, Somalia. Afghanistan In 2019, security issues prevented DDG from commencing clearance operations in Maydan Wardak province as planned (postponed until 2020/2021, if security and Covid-19 pandemic allows). Instead DDG carried out work in Balkh and Samangan provinces. Due to this as well as prioritisation by the national authorities there was more focus on Battle Area Clearance than mine field clearance during the year. Out of the total 1,953,216m2 land released 1,645,864 was through Battle Area Clearance while 307,352m2 was minefield clearance. This is a slightly lower output than 2018 but since no minefields were cleared in 2018 and that type of clearance is more labour intensive and since the overall target of land released is on par with the annual target Sida assesses that the work is well on track. Regarding risk education DDG delivered more than double of the annual target number of sessions. 2,094 risk education sessions were conducted which benefitted 34,417 (also that an overachievement of 170 %) with a significant focus on children (12,856 girls, 13,404 boys, 4,006 women and 4,151 men). Iraq Under Sida funding in 2019 MAG and DDG teams released 938,978m² of land, with 39,314 people reached through 2,685 Risk education sessions. Out of this MAG released 347,889 m² of cleared land in the villages Moftiya ad Zahra Khatoon Kabeer in Hamdaniya district, Ninewa Governorate. In relation to the target of square meters cleared this 86 % of the annual target. DDG on their part conducted Battle Area Clearance along the Tigris river in Mosul, which resulted in 591,089 m² being cleared, 59 % of the annual target. MAG responded to 260 explosive ordinance diposal spot tasks across Dohuk Governorate in 2019, which resulted in 210 dangerous items of various kinds being destroyed. On mine risk education, DDG delivered 1,724 risk education sessions benefitting 20,738 individuals (3,336 women, 5,679 men, 5,910 girls and 5,813 boys) which was 95 % of the target number of risk education sessions for 2019. MAG delivered 961 risk education sessions, which is significantly higher than the output of 2018 and 90 % of the 2019 target. MAG's risk education benefitted 18,576 individuals and since there was a focus on schools 8, 296 boys, 6,415 girls, 2,559 men and 1,306 women benefitted from the risk education.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
